This is a review for the Linux version, running Ubuntu 14.10. Runs perfectly on linux, only minor issue is lack of an exit button.   I was hesitant to pick this game up, due to the artstyle that seemed lazy in the screenshots and the general simplicity of bullet hell games. I was expecting this to be a cheap 'So retro' game. However, when it went on sale and I noticed it was published by Devolver Digital (who have yet to back a stray horse) I decided to give it a go. I'm glad I did and I would recommend this game at full price.  This game reminds me of old arcade classic Aerial Dogfight, except with everything turned to the max. You begin with only the most basic machine gun and engine, then when you die you've discovered that you have a new engine that lets you move twice as fast at the cost of turning speed, a few more deaths later you're erupting out of the ocean and obliterating everything with a laser strapped to a chassis which is a nuclear bomb.  The game offers a lot of upgrade potential, it's surprisingly balanced. There's no combination which felt leagues better than the rest, Although your basic machinegun, chassis and engine feel outdated by the end, nothing you have earned will feel pointless.  The constant flow of gameplay challenges associated with each weapon encourages you to diversify your tactics. This prevents the fact that the game only offers one level and one mode from becoming tedious. One downside of these challenges is that the curve on them is a little bit off. The final challenges are magnitudes more difficuklt than the ones that came before it, and something such as defeating a submarine at MAX combo feels far more luck based than it does skill based.  The only real downside I could say against this game is that once you've completed all the challenges, there's not much to do but try for the high-score. That's not even a problem either with a relatively short round time and tight polished gameplay. I can see myself coming back to this many times in the future.

While it seems like a pretty simple 2D shooter, just flying around trying to stay alive and get a top score, it has some nice features that add to its replayability.  GREAT Music. I'm not sure why they haven't made the soundtrack available on Steam, but I have seen one available in music bundles.  As you try to stay alive, you can also attempt to complete missions to unlock upgrades. These range from easy (kill X enemies) to challenging (kill the feared Blimp!).  There are different upgrades for Gun, Hull, and Engine, as well as a randomizer option.  If you like shooters, you will probably like this!

Luftrausers is a game where you fly around in a plane that can do crazy maneuvers and shoot enemies until you die. Pretty simple, pretty hectic gameplay, pretty insane, and on that note, insanely fun to play.  The gameplay is controled with 4 buttons; left, right, boost and fire. These buttons can be configured to your liking in the options menu, and you can even play with a gamepad. The goal of the game is to eliminate as many enemies as you can before you get shot down. Fortunately, you don't die in one hit; instead, the game makes a shaded circle around your plane indicating your health. The closer said circle is to your plane, the lower your health. You can recover health by simply not firing, but this means you'd potentially lose any scoring combos you had going, encouraging high-risk, high-reward gameplay while not penalizing you for playing it safe.   The missions (i.e. subquests that unlock parts for your Luftrauser) start out simple, but quickly get tedious, annoying and often luck-based; as such, I would not recommend this game for hardcore completionists. However, it's fairly easy to unlock all ship parts relatively quickly (except for the final ultimate Luftrauser obtained from 100% mission completion), allowing for flexible gameplay that can suit your playing style.   In conclusion, Luftrausers is a fast-paced aerial shootout that only loses its fun value if you focus more on completing the missions for achievements rather than obliterating every enemy you see.

LUFTRAUSERS contains some of the most clever mechanics design and balancing you're likely to have seen for a while. Though there are only really three mechanics (Rotate, thrust, shoot), the way they fit together is stunning; releasing thrust is crucial for avoiding enemy fire, and you can only repair damage when you aren't firing yourself. The end result is both chaotic and balletic. Add to this a superb metagame, where you unlock new parts by completing micro-challenges, and it's hard to recommend this game enough.

An excellent game !  Pure arcade game. The controls are simple, and you should feel immediately taken by the frantic gameplay. Each play will last between 10s and a few minutes, depending on how good you are at dodging the endless streams of enemies bullets. But of course, you will want more, and in a few seconds you will be up in the air again trying to beat your previous score.  You might think that this wouldn't be fun for hours if you're not into 'getting the highscore' mentality. But Vlambeer (the studio who developped LUFTRAUSERS), manage to take that simple idea of an arcade dogfighting game, and add something more.   Your plane has 3 parts (Gun, Body, Engine) which you will soon be able to modify. There are 5 different parts of each type, which allow for lots of variation. More importantly, most parts are 'side-grades', which mean unlocked parts are not better, but different than the original parts. Each part requires you to adapt your gameplay, and will offer different strengths and weaknesses.  To encourage you to try all the parts, each part is linked to several 'missions', which are challenges you can accomplish with that part. For example 'Killing 5 different enemies types in a single game', 'Getting 5000 points in a single game', 'Kill 150 enemies accross all playthrough', etc... Theses are not mandatory, but will allow you to unlock other parts and a few other hidden stuff.   While trying to perform theses challenges, you will get to understand the different parts better, and find that some suits you better than others. I've often dismissed a specific part as weak, until i tried to complete its missions and figured out how to best use it (which part should go with which, and how to adapt my gameplay to the new plane). My 3 best scores have been with 3 different planes.   Also it's very telling that in forum threads asking 'what's the best plane for doing X ?' all theses answers will vary wildly. There is no 'best' plane. It's all about personal tastes and how you use each plane. So congratulations to Vlambeer for managing to balance all theses parts together.  All of that means that, over the simple arcade gameplay, there is that metagame to try to finish all missions. It may or may not please everybody, but i know it keeps me playing way more than a basic 'aim for the highscore' game would.  It's quite easy to unlock all parts, so no player should frustrated that they lack part, but for hardcore players, unlocking everything is gonna be a true challenge. Achievements stats show that less than 1% of players have managed to finish all missions.

Okay... this game... is awesome! it's amazingly (addictively) fun to pilot a plane like this. the mechanic of your plane being repaired whenever you don't shoot is ingenious, adding a bit of risk vs. reward to every second of play. each new part adds to the experience, and whenever I got frustrated, I found myself switching out a part or two to create a completely different play style, and the pallette swaps are a nice touch.   However, there are a few gripes I have with the game. Several enemies can take you out in a snap, sometimes when they're not even on screen. I've had several occasions where I've gotten out of an intense dogfight with only a scrap of health left (with little else on the screen) only for a jet to zoom in and smack into me. Battleships either need less health or shoot less bullets, and an ace can often times take you out before you have any time to react. For several hours, most of my objectives consisted of 'take out a blimp to continue', but I can't for the life of me tell you the spawn conditions for one (sometimes they appeared 30 seconds in, sometimes three minutes of intense fighting will pass with niether hide nor hair). Blimps don't spawn nearly often enough to develop a strategy, and when I finally did beat one it was by dying with the kamikaze bomb part.  Despite it's shortcomings, however, LUFTRAUSERS' ten dollar asking price seems about right as an asking price, and I'd definitely buy it again. I can see myself sinking plenty more hours into this game.

After about an hour of playtime, you will have seen enough to know what to expect from this game. That is not a bad thing in this instance because Luftrausers is a great arcade experience that relies heavily on gameplay and control. Not much of a campaign or story to speak of, but the dogfighting feels sublime. Turning your customizeable aircraft in mid air after cutting the thrusters gives you a cool sense of gravity that reminds me of an old school game but with modern tight control. The devs haven't crammed a jillion gameplay elements into this hoping to add 'variety' either. The core gameplay stands on it's own and let's you get right into the fray without a lot of BS. And when you die, and you will, you'll be right back out there fighting it out within seconds if you wish. This is what I want from indie games. A game that doesn't try to pad out the experience to feel like a big title, instead Luftrausers does one thing uniquely and extremely well and with a lot of style.

LUFTRAUSERS (roughly translates to 'air-routers'?!?!) is extremely personable and conservatively enjoyable. The soundtrack is award worthy and the game is presented really well visually. I can't say comfortably that the simplistic left-right-stop-go flight play is as sensational as the feeling provided by flying a little too close to sea level, but the controls are responsive and the physics just berserk enough to provide fast game play that doesn't feel as acid-trippy as something like Geometry Wars. This is quite bullet hellish, but difficulty comes from maneuvering an airplane with two speeds (on and off) rather than raw, unfair amounts of projectiles.   All in all it is a very charismatic arcade game with a scare amount of content but a **** ton of flavor. A good ten dollar game, a great five dollar game, and an even better summer sale clearance type of game.

Someone once said this game has 'styyyyyyyle'. Well, I'm happy to report It has it in spades my friends.   Luftrausers is basically Asteroids with gravity and World War I planes instead of spaceships. You have goals that will unlock new parts for your plane that not only change the look and capabilities of your own craft, but also give the music a specific spin depending on the part you attach. This actually adds a lot to the game's minimal but stellar sound track.   There is no better feeling than when you become the plane! What I mean by that, is the moment when you wrap you mind around the controls. Then, before you know it, you're weaving in and out of a few battleship's bullet spray, while pulling a 180 to boost THROUGH your pursuers. Okay, so maybe its more than Asteroids with gravity and WWI planes, and thats why I love it.  Recommend it to a friend, Tino

So, I'm just a few parts combinations away from full completion of this game, and wow. Just... wow.  You start off in a pretty simple manner; you have a standard machine gun, normal armour, and an engine. Letting go of up stalls the engine, allowing you to begin drifting back to the water. Entering the clouds or the water causes you damage, to start with anyway. Stop firing, and any damage you took begins to regenerate. And that's the nice, simple start.  By the end... Well, you'll be flying around furiously, firing giant fireballs that explode on impact with an enemy, equipped with a submarine propeller so water no longer hurts you, with the fuselage of a nuke that explodes on your death. Oh, and there'll be a siren going off, and not long after it's likely you'll be dead.  And eventually, after some seriously difficult challenges... you'll unlock the U-Rauser, and boy, you probably didn't see that coming. But you'll have enjoyed every second.
pro tip: you can play it online as a flash game  it's still honestly worth buying, considering its fun as hell and the profile backgrounds are pretty damn sweet.

This game is another shining diamond from Devolver Digital, makers of one of my all-time game series Hotline Miami. (It even features some recycled Hotline Miami musik, so you know that part is wonderful.)  A triumph for pixel art in games.  Works off the principle that what goes up must come down (YES!--gravity), using this physic to create a whole new twist to twin-stick shooter arcade play. Also, playing like a suicide-bomber can be to your advantage as you can use your plane to melee enemies as well as to fire missles. Very challenging gameplay (the achievements will most likely not be hard to cook through, but the game itself provides a beautiful challenge and you can compete for high scores).  The art is simplistic, but subdued, easy on the eyes, and beautiful. The art style is unique and fun, the kind of art you would expect from Devolver. Beige color-scheme is interesting. Play-style is customizable (you can alter weapons/parts of the ship).  The gravity mechanic doesn't make sense in light of the German war Aero-plane theme, but oh well. It's a video game and absurdity is welcome. The sky and water serve as a function of the game, not just backdrop, so I guess it all works.  I came to love this game in a very short time and this is definitely doing to be one of my top picks for a long while.

LUFTRAUSERS is pretty much what it looks like: an arcade dogfighter. I was expecting a story mode or something similar, but all I got was a straightforward 2D shoot-em-up. That having been said, I am not in the least disappointed by what I received; this game knows what it does and does it well. It provides the classic arcade experience of scoring as much as possible without dying, throwing in for bonus the rush of excitement when you stall in midair, watching hordes of enemies and waves of bullets streak past you in a whirlwind of death. The stalling mechanic is really what makes this game so good; you can stop accelerating and simply let gravity do the work of dodging hazards for you, then after changing direction speed up at the last second and escape the jaws of death. Obviously it's not a lot of content, despite the number of ship parts allowing for a commendable combination of ships and thus playstyles. For what I paid, however, I'd say I easily got my money's worth.

'LUFTRAUSERS' is kind of an interesting indie game; it takes place in an alternate history setting, where in World War II, Adolf Hitler never came into power. So, in this universe, the Germans were allies, and the Nazi party never existed.  The enemies in the game are the Japanese, the Russians, and the Italians. It's an interesting game where the main protagonist is a fictional World War II pilot.  Anyways, the gameplay is quite interesting; with interestingly made 2-D graphics with a distinct 'retro-like' feel to them, a high quality soundtrack, and interesting yet simple gameplay, this sure beats having to play the video game, 'Gods & Generals'. I highly reccomend this game, for anyone who likes alternate history-themed games. It's quite challenging, but it's supposed to be. I give it 4/5, saying that it's a simple, yet quite fun game, though $9.99 seems kinda pricy for this game, (I would reccommend getting this whenever it goes on sale) but if you're a die-hard fan of alternate history games or simply excellent indie games, GO FOR IT, because for a simple arcade-based space shooter, it's AWESOME!

When LUFTRAUSERS goes, it really GOES.   Your fighter aircraft launches into the air. Give it a second or two, and a horde of smaller planes start chasing it. Battleships fire at you from below. And then larger planes start bringing down the pressure before a blimp threatens to obliterate you (that is, if you haven’t been obliterated already).  Your challenge is to survive the frenetic action and take down these vessels as you weave through the enemy fire. The balancing act of returning fire and then letting off to allow your fighter reprieve to heal up is core to your gameplay.  Experimenting with the different combinations of craft parts, completing missions and racking up higher and higher scores is all part of the fun here. LUFTRAUSERS is THE modern bullet hell-esque / arcade shooter game.

Although LUFTRAUSERS is not a SHMUP  in the traditional sense , I'm still gonna call it  'SHMUP ON DRUG'  due to it's bullet hell and thre adrenaline rush.  The gameplay is simple yet clever and addictive. You try to stay alive using customizable parts to suit your own play style. The 'stop-shooting-to-regenerate-health' mechanic keeps you focus on the most important part, KILL and STAY ALIVE, rather than putting you in difficult situations where you died just because you need to grab 'that healing item'  The control is very responsive, although a bit confusing at first (if you're used to the six/eight axis free movement implemented in modern games), in LUFTRUASERS, you use LEFT/RIGHT to pivot/rotate your plane and UP to use the throttle/forward, but once you get used to it (and learned to master the control for the part combination you of your choice), you'll be going for the kill! This is a pretty dang fun game to screw around in when you've got nothing else going on. It controls well and is extremely fast-paced and engaging. I love the little flavorful elements they injected into the game, like the music changing depending on which parts you're using. The selection of said parts is cool, and they each change the feel of the game drastically. I really dislike the homing missiles because even with the bomb or melee body it's just too hard to kill anything large, and their accuracy is surprisingly finicky given that their weak damage and low rate of fire suggests that their one trade-off should be an inability to miss. I still have two challenges to complete (not counting SFMT challenges), so I don't know what the [CLASSIFIED] is like, but my favorite Rausers are 'Holy Diver' and 'Staff Pick.'  However, I feel fairly emasculated by the number of digits in the score display. Do people actually score hundreds of thousands of points at this? My high score is like 30,000, and that's because most games I play spawn three battleships in on me at the same time and I honestly don't understand how you're supposed to deal with three battleships given their range and rate of fire. I mean, seriously, even though I'm pretty good at killing battleships now, how the hell am I supposed to kill three of them when a new one willl just spawn in its place? In other words, I think this game would be better if it chilled out a bit when it comes to what it spawns in and how quickly it spawns it. To be fair, each game certainly gets interesting quickly.  That aside, highly recommend it. It's stylish, extremely well produced and just plane fun. PLANE FUN GET IT

LUFTRAUSERS (the title is, apparently, all caps) is a very simple 2D arcade-style game. You control a plane which flies around and shoots enemy planes. Unlike a schmup, where you proceed left-to-right or top-to-bottom, this is a side view, looking at a plane flying over an ocean, dogfighting vertically and firing on boats below.  The game has a highly non-standard control scheme – you can fire, you can boost, and you can pitch your plane up and down, in a full 360 degree circle. The controls are very simple and kind of unusual, but you get the hang of them after a while.  The game has 8 different enemy types – basic planes, a nastier kind of plane, giant blimps, basic boats, submarines, battleships, and two rare enemy types which almost never spawn. You will encounter them all in fairly short order, and at that point, you’ve seen all that the game really has to offer – there is an alternate mode which is basically a bullet hell mode, but even the regular mode can start bordering on that at times.  You can customize your plane with five different weapons, five different bodies, and five different engines, each of which alter the gameplay of the game in reasonably significant ways, but ultimately the variety granted by these unlockable parts wears off after a short while. There are in-game missions which allow you to unlock parts and color schemes, each of which is attached to one of the parts, with each part having six such missions attached to it. If you beat all the missions, you unlock a final, alternate plane.  Really, this game is decent enough gameplay wise, but it just doesn’t have much depth to it. It is really simple and there just isn’t much variety to it in the end, so you’re likely to get bored with it after a short time.  If you got it as part of a bundle or something, it might be worth looking at, but it just isn’t worth buying – it just feels too simple to feel like an adequate stand-alone game.

An awful trip to a level of graphics that really should be left in an era, circa 1988. I understand the 'retro' need for nostalgia - with the 16 (and sometimes) 8-bit looking games being popular these last couple of years. But this really does dip to a whole new level.  Essentially, you've got a weird hybrid game of Altitude meeting a set piece from Access's classic Beach-Head from 1984. Except both of these games are more fun. Anyone old enough to remember another classic - Domark's 'Wings of Fury' will also find this familiar - but again, the shooting planes and attacking ships was much better done in that game too.  I really am puzzled as to what they were trying to achieve with this game. It feels clumsy, truly horrific to look at in 2014 and just ultimately a very boring, bland game to play. I really wish I'd bothered with a demo before forking out even my measely £6.99 for it. It's not even worth that.  1/10

Wish I could reccomend this game, because it COULD have been great. The controls are responsive and the graphics is nice. The sound and music however is just annoying, which sadly matches gameplay well. Enemy airplanes and boats have a godly aim, that every thing off screen always know your exact position and the bulletspam is awful. The controls are not accurate enough to make it a fun 'bullet-dodge' game, instead the controls make you feel engaged in duels - but it's not much about that, game is mostly about finding a cheese-tactic in order to scratch another mission off your list.  Every combination of gun/ship/boost make you feel crippled with drawbacks - you never feel like you are particularly strong or efficient, you just feel like a slug trying to all-in for a mission clear; die, repeat.  Drawbacks on all gear should be adjusted - it makes no sense that EVERYTHING has so strong drawbacks that you ALWAYS feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Want spread-fire? Ok cool, but you can barely shoot upward now because the kickback is so strong that you lose all elevation. Want laser? Sure, but now your aim sucks so you can barely make turns. Want to be able to handle collision? Sure, but now you die from 3 bullets instead.   Makes the game feel like a frustrating chose unfortunately.
